questions.text:
A homeless man is caught peeping into the women's public restroom and attaining sexual gratification. This act is punishable under which section of the BNS?

BNS - Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita

IPC - Indian Penal Code
questions.solution:
The scenario is suggestive of voyeurism and is punishable under BNS Section 77 (IPC 354-C).

Voyeurism refers to an individual having an intense desire to observe unsuspecting people undress or naked, take a bath, see genitalia, or watch intercourse to attain sexual excitement or gratification. The individual is called a voyeur or a peeping tom.

The punishment for this offence is imprisonment for not less than 1 year which may extend to 3 years and a fine. If the voyeur repeats the offense, they can be punished with imprisonment of 3-7 years.

BNS Section 74 (IPC 354) deals with assault or use of force on a woman to insult her modesty. Such acts are punishable with imprisonment of 1-5 years and a fine.

The other related offenses are given below:

76 354-B Assaulting or forcing a woman to disrobe

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man files a case against a surgeon who left a cotton swab within him after a hernia repair. Which of the following best describes this scenario of medical negligence?

BNSS- Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita
questions.solution:
Res ipsa loquitur best describes this scenario under medical negligence.

Res ipsa loquitur means the facts of the case speak for themselves.

Normally, in cases of medical negligence, the burden of proof lies on the patient to prove the doctor guilty. However, the patient need not prove any negligence under Res ipsa loquitur.

The conditions to be fulfilled for Res Ipsa Loquitur are:

  • The injury or damage would not have occurred without negligence
  • The doctor is in exclusive control of the instrumentation or circumstances
  • The patient must not contribute to his own injury or damage

Several situations can be used as defences by the doctor against medical negligence. This includes no duty owed to the plaintiff/ patient, the doctor's duty has been discharged according to prevailing standards, a scenario of misadventure that may be therapeutic, diagnostic, and experimental, or an error of judgment.

Other options:

Option A: Res judicata - BNSS Section 337 (CrPC 300) states that if a question of negligence against a doctor has already been decided by a court in a dispute between the doctor and his patient, the patient will not be allowed to contest the same question.

Option C: Limitation or Res indicata indicates that a suit for damages for negligence should be filed against the doctor within two years from the date of alleged negligence. A suit filed after two years will be dismissed. But, where a breach of duty to provide care as per a particular contract between a patient and a doctor is committed, legal action can be initiated up to three years from the date of alleged negligence.

Option D: Novus Actus Interveniens is a situation where the cause of disability or death passes from the doctor to a later negligent action of some other person. It means a person is responsible not only for his actions but also for the logical consequences of those actions. For a plea of Novus actus, an element of negligence is absolutely essential.

Related Pearl: Contributory negligence

Contributory negligence occurs when a patient or his personal attendant shows unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care, which when combined with the negligence of the doctor, has contributed to the injury. In this case, the patient’s or attendant’s negligence should be the direct, proximate cause and without which the injury would not have occurred.

So, contributory negligence occurs when both the doctor and patient are negligent. The direct or proximate cause of the injury should be the patient’s negligence, which means that if the patient was not negligent, the injury could have been prevented.

Contributory negligence usually occurs when the doctor is negligent and the patient:

  • Fails to give an accurate medical history, and as a result, the doctor may misdiagnose or mistreat the patient.
  • Fails to follow the doctor’s instructions
  • Refuses to take the treatment
  • Leaves the hospital against doctor’s advice
  • Does not inform the doctor or seek further medical assistance if the symptoms persist or worsens.

Contributory negligence is a defence for doctor’s negligence in civil cases. However, from case to case, the liability of a doctor may vary from complete non-liability to substantial liability for the damages. Under the doctrine of comparative negligence, the court has the right to hold both parties liable for their negligent actions.

Limitations / Exceptions to contributory negligence:

A. The doctor will be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. The doctor failed to provide proper instructions to the patient

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and did not tell the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (no proper instruction). The patient develops numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

 2. Last clear chance doctrine: It is applicable when the doctor fails to take necessary action to prevent damage due to a negligent act of the patient, even after getting a clear chance to take such action.

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and told the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (gave proper instruction). The patient developed numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). Next day patient informed the doctor, but the doctor did not remove the cast and said he was busy (There was a clear last chance, but the doctor neglected again). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

B. The doctor/person will not be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. Avoidable consequences rule: It occurs when an injury is caused due to doctor’s negligence, and the patient has done a negligent act, which further aggravated the injury caused by the doctor, and the patient could have avoided the consequence by not doing such act. In such cases, the doctor need not pay anything, and the patient will be held guilty.

  • Ex: A patient had a lacerated wound. The doctor examined the patient and had not done any dressing or provided any antibiotics (the doctor is negligent). However, the doctor instructed the patient to avoid contamination and asked him to visit the clinic next week. When the patient went home, he applied cow dung on his wound every day thinking that the wound would heal faster and didn't visit the doctor after one week. The wound got infected and developed pus and aggravated the injury.
  • Here, despite the doctor being negligent in the first instance, the patient is responsible for his injury as he performed an unnecessary, avoidable act, which aggravated the injury. The doctor need not pay anything.

2. Good Samaritan doctrine: A person who assists another person who is in serious danger cannot be charged with contributory negligence. unless such assistance is reckless or rash.

  • Ex: A person was travelling on a road and saw a car accident, where the victim was unconscious and was stuck inside the car. He called the ambulance. The paramedical staff instructed him not to mobilize the victim until they arrived. Meanwhile, the car was caught in fire (serious danger), and the person tried to remove the victim carefully out of the car (assisted the victim and was not reckless). However, the victim already had a cervical bone fracture due to the accident, which got mobilized while he was being removed out of the car and as a result, suffered an injury to the spine that led to paralysis (victim’s injury was aggravated). In such a case, the good samaritan doctrine would apply and the person who tried to help, will not be charged under contributory negligence.

questions.text: Magistrate's inquest is done in all, except
questions.solution:
Magistrate's inquest is not done in a case of death due to drowning.

A magistrate’s inquest is an inquest conducted by a District Magistrate, Subdivisional Magistrate, and magistrate of the first class rank or any other magistrate as empowered by the State Government, such as Collector, Deputy Collector, or Tehsildar (Executive Magistrates).

Special Magistrate’s inquests are held in cases of:

  • Lock-up deaths
  • Deaths while under police interrogation
  • Deaths in prison
  • Deaths in police custody
  • Deaths due to police firing
  • Exhumation
  • Alleged dowry death
  • In all cases where the police normally conduct inquests, magistrate can hold an additional inquest, or in place of the police inquest.

Note: It is practiced throughout India. However, it is not held routinely but held only on special indications mentioned above. In any case of unnatural death, the magistrate may hold an inquest instead of/ in addition to the police inquest.

Police Inquest: The inquest is held by a police officer (called Investigating Officer) not below the rank of Senior Head Constable. It is practised throughout India.

questions.text: Accidental ingestion of the insect shown below is associated with which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
The insect is identified as the Spanish fly. Accidental consumption is associated with priapism.

Spanish fly is a winged insect with a length of 2 cm and a breadth of 0.6 cm with greenish-black color and shiny wings. It contains the toxic active principle cantharidin.

The active principle can be absorbed through the skin and all mucosa. On local application to the skin or mucosa, it is associated with redness of skin, and burning pain followed by vesication of the skin. The sequela of cantharides ingestion involves priapism. Features of this poisoning are severe thirst, dysphagia, priapism, genital pain, tenesmus, and convulsions resulting in coma and death. Abortion can occur if the woman is pregnant.

Treatment is symptomatic and if ingested, stomach wash needs to be done along with the administration of demulcents.

Other Options: 

Option A: Acrodynia is seen in chronic mercury poisoning, in which there is pain and pink discoloration of the hands and feet.

Option C: Raindrop pigmentation is a finely mottled brown change on skin flexures, temples, eyelids, and necks seen in arsenic poisoning.

Option D: Magnan’s sign is seen in cocaine addicts where they experience and interpret paraesthesia as the constant movement of a foreign body or bugs under their skin.

questions.text: The technique of autopsy characterized by in situ dissection is:
questions.solution:
Rokitansky technique is characterised by ‘in situ’ dissection, in part, combined with removal of organ blocks.

Related Pearl: Autopsy Techniques

  • Virchow's technique: Organs are removed one by one from the body to be examined. Here the cranial cavity is opened first, then the spinal cord, followed by thoracic, cervical, and abdominal organs in that order.
  • Ghon's technique: Here the organs are removed 'en bloc'. The thoracic, cervical, pelvic, and abdominal organs are removed as organ blocks.
  • Rokitansky's technique: This is characterized by 'in situ' dissection in part combined with en bloc removal like Ghon's technique. The dissection begins at the neck and slowly works its way down the body and the organ is removed as a bloc. A cut is first made at the larynx to separate the esophagus from the pharynx. The larynx and trachea are pulled downward and using a scalpel, the chest organs are cut. The diaphragm is cut to expose the abdominal organs. Other organs like the bladder and rectum are separated from the body by using a scalpel to cut the pelvic ligaments.
  • Letulle's technique: Thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed 'en masse' meaning as one big organ block. It allows the body to be made available for examination in less than 30 minutes as the process of removing the organs is much quicker.

questions.text: An 89-year-old woman was seen dead at home. Her bloodstained clothes were sent for examination to your forensic laboratory. On adding a reagent, feathery crystals of hemochromogen arranged in clusters appeared in 5 minutes.  What is the test done?
questions.solution:
The test done in the above scenario is the Takayama test.

The Takayama test or hemochromogen crystal test is a microchemical test used to detect bloodstains. The stain used is Takayama reagent. If bloodstain is present, pink feathery crystals of hemochromogen or reduced alkaline hematin appear in a few minutes. The test is negative if the crystals are not formed in 30 minutes. This test is more reliable and gives positive results with old stains.

Other options:

Option B: The Teichmann test or hemin crystal test is also a test used to detect bloodstains. The stain used glacial acetic acid and a small crystal of sodium chloride. If bloodstain is present, faint yellowish-red to brownish-black rhombic crystals of hemin or hematin chloride appear. When hydrogen peroxide is added, the hematin crystals give bubbles of gas.

Option C: The Barberio test is used to detect seminal fluid. When a saturated aqueous or alcoholic solution of picric acid is added to the spermatic fluid, yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals of spermine picrate are produced.

Option D: The Florence test is used to detect the presence of semen. The stain used is 10% hydrochloric acid and Florence solution (potassium iodide, iodine, and water). If semen is present, dark brown rhombic or needle-shaped crystals of choline iodide appear immediately.

questions.text: From a crime scene, you recover a fingerprint that is of a loop pattern. Which of the following patterns most likely represents the same?
questions.solution:
Image A shows the Loop type of fingerprint. It is the most common type of fingerprint. 

A - Looped Pattern - 60–70%

B - Whorl - 29%

C - Arched - 3%

D - Tented Arch - 3%

Fingerprint first develops in 12–16 weeks of intrauterine life and is complete by 24 weeks. They are the impressions of patterns produced by the papillary or epidermal ridges present on the fingertips. The arrangement and distribution of the ridges not only remain unchanged throughout life but are unique for each individual. The study of this ridge pattern in the skin is called dermatoglyphics or dactylography and helps in the identification of an individual.

Edgeoscopy is the study of edges of friction ridges, which normally show seven characteristic features. Ridgeology is the study of friction ridges, which are composed of the edges of ridge units that vary in size, shape, and alignment.

questions.text: A patient was brought dead to the casualty. Fundoscopy exhibits the sign as shown in the image given below. Which of the following is the most accurate inference regarding the time of death?
questions.solution:
The image in the above clinical scenario shows the Kevorkian sign. Hence, the most accurate time of death is less than 1 hour.

Kevorkian sign is a postmortem change that occurs in the retinal vessels and lasts for about 1 hour. This means that the patient had died within the preceding hour. 

It is characterized by fragmentation of the blood column in the retinal vessels and occurs due to loss of blood pressure. It appears within minutes after death and lasts for about 1 hour. It can be visualized using an ophthalmoscope.

Other postmortem changes occurring in the eye:

  • Cornea: Dull, hazy, opaque, wrinkled.
  • Flaccidity of eyeballs occurs due to a fall in intraocular pressure (IOP). IOP reaches zero at the end of 2 hours after death.
  • Increase in potassium concentration in vitreous:  Linear increase up to 100 hours following death.
  • Tache noir: One of the post-mortem ocular signs. A film of cell debris and mucus forms two yellow triangles on the sclera on either side of the cornea, with the base towards the margin of the cornea and the apex towards the medial or lateral canthus of the eye which becomes brown and then black. It appears within 3-4 hours of death.

questions.text: The forensic department has received the post-mortem remains of a partly decayed body recovered from the outskirts near an international airport. The cephalic index of the skull is 82 and the hair appears circular on the cross-section. Dental examination shovel-shaped upper incisors and enamel pearls. What will be your inference about the race from these findings?
questions.solution:
The cephalic index of the skull being 82 (Brachycephalic), the hair being circular on cross-section, and the dentition showing characteristic shovel-shaped upper incisors and enamel pearls is suggestive of a Mongoloid race.

Features of Mongoloid dentition:

  • Shovel-shaped upper central incisors - Posterior surfaces of these teeth have a depression centrally
  • Enamel pearls - Small nodules of enamel on the tooth surface
  • The pulp cavity of molars is wide and deep
  • A congenital lack of the third upper molar is common but nonspecific.

Negroid races tend to have large teeth and often have more cusps on their molars, even up to eight, with two lingual cusps on the mandibular first premolars as an additional common finding.

In Caucasian races, the lateral incisors in the upper jaw are usually smaller than the central. They also have long pointed canine roots. Small nodules on the lingual surface of maxillary molars, called ‘Carabelli’s cusp’, are most common in Caucasian races.

Race determination from Hair:

Race Hair cross-section
Negroids Elliptical
Caucasoids Round to Ovoid
Mongoloids Circular


The Cephalic Index is used to determine the race of the individual.

Cranial index = Maximum skull breadth x 100 / Maximum skull length

There are three main racial groups: Caucasian, Mongoloid, and Negroid. All the skulls cannot be accurately differentiated into the 3 broad categories because of racial mixing.

The skull offers the best evidence of racial origins.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient developed severe abdominal pain, vertigo, and convulsions after the consumption of the seeds shown in the image. Which of the following is the toxin present in this seed?
questions.solution:
The seeds shown in the image are those of the Abrus precatorius plant. Abrin is one of the toxic principles of this plant.

Toxic principles of Abrus precatorius:

  • Abrin (a toxalbumen)
  • Abrine (an amino acid)
  • Abralin (a glucoside)

Abrin acts by inhibiting protein synthesis, thereby resulting in cell death. The clinical features after oral ingestion of these seeds include abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, bloody diarrhea, weakness, cold perspiration, trembling, weak rapid pulse, and miosis. Faintness, vertigo, dyspnea, and convulsions can also occur. If taken by injection, painful swelling, ecchymosis with inflammation, and necrosis are seen at the site of injection.

Medicolegal Importance:

  • It is commonly used as cattle poison in Indian villages by injecting the seed extract into the animal in the form of certain fine needle-shaped structures known as sui (meaning needle in Hindi).
  • These are prepared by mixing the seed extract with opium, datura, and spirit/water and then blended into a paste, shaped into fine needles and dried in the sun, and used to kill cattle by driving it deep into the animal body by blowing through a hollow bamboo pipe.

Other options:

Option A: Ricin is the toxic principle of the Ricinus communis plant. It causes the burning of oral mucosa similar to alkali burn, severe abdominal pain, hemolysis, convulsions, uremia, collapse, and death. 

The image below shows the seeds of Ricinus communis.

Option B- Crotin is the toxic principle of Croton tiglium. They present with hot burning pain from mouth to stomach, salivation, purging, vertigo, prostration, collapse, and death.

The image below shows the seeds of Croton tiglium.

Option D- Capsaicin is the toxic principle of Capsicum annum. Consuming in large doses causes difficulty in swallowing, abdominal pain, and inflammation of the esophagus and stomach.

questions.text: A chronic substance user was brought with complaints of depression, hypersomnia, and craving. History revealed that he had not been consuming the said substance for the past few days. What is the likely substance that was being consumed in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of cocaine withdrawal symptoms.

Cocaine withdrawal is a triphasic syndrome that presents after the sudden stoppage of chronic cocaine use. The phases are as follows - 

  1. Crash phase (9 hours-4 days): Anorexia, depression, excessive craving, hypersomnia, fatigue.
  2. Normal mood, anxiety, and anhedonia (4-7 days)
  3. Extinction phase (7-10 days): Absence of withdrawal symptoms but increased susceptibility to relapse.

Treatment for withdrawal includes bromocriptine and amantadine. They are useful in reducing cocaine cravings.

Other options:

Option A: Shakes, hallucinations, and agitation are symptoms of alcohol withdrawal syndrome. They occur 12-24 hours following alcohol intake. Other features include nausea, vomiting, malaise, anxiety, depression, and headache. 

Delirium tremens begin 72 to 96 hours after the last drink. It is due to the long-continued action of the poison on the brain. It occurs in chronic alcoholics due to temporary excess, sudden withdrawal of alcohol, shock after receiving an injury, such as fracture of a bone, or from acute infection, such as pneumonia, influenza, erysipelas, etc.

Option C: Profuse sweating, diarrhea, and piloerection (gooseflesh) are symptoms of opioid withdrawal. They are associated with nausea, vomiting, lacrimation, rhinorrhea, muscle cramps, and generalized body aches. These symptoms manifest about 12-24 hours after the stoppage and recede within 7-10 days of last use.

Option D: Synesthesia or seeing smells and hearing colors and flashback phenomenon (emotional and psychological experiences of the previous LSD) are features of lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) intoxication. Other features include dry mouth, dilated pupils, tachycardia, hypertension, mood changes, visual hallucinations, alterations in time perceptions, vision, and hearing. Side effects are psychosis, depression, panic attacks, and schizophrenic episodes.

questions.text: A 21-year-old boy is brought by his parents with a history of nausea, anxiety, confusion, and delusions. He gives a history of ingestion of a beverage containing dried leaves and fruiting shoots of the following plant. Urine testing reveals positive traces of tetrahydrocannabinol. What is the most likely preparation used by him?
questions.solution:
The most likely preparation used by him is bhang.

The clinical vignette of a boy presenting with nausea, anxiety, confusion, and delusions subsequent to ingestion of a beverage made from the leaves of the cannabis plant, in addition to the presence of tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) in the urine is indicative of acute THC intoxication.

Bhang is a preparation of dried leaves and fruiting shoots of the Cannabis plant which is ingested. It can be taken as a bolus or pills or mixed with water and strained through a muslin cloth before it is drunk.

The effects of THC depend upon dosage, frequency, route of administration, the experience and expectations of the individual, smoking technique, the amount destroyed by pyrolysis, and how quickly the drug is used. 

Acute intoxication is characterized by a feeling of cheerfulness and well-being and appetite is increased. Impaired memory, reaction time, perception, motor coordination, and attention are other common symptoms.

Large doses can give rise to nausea, anxiety, confusion, hallucinations, and delusions. Persons with an excitable temperament may exhibit violent behaviour. This is followed by a stage of narcosis characterized by giddiness, confusion, drowsiness, dilated pupils, and tingling and numbness of the extremities.

questions.text: An elderly woman presents to the clinic with a history of a tingling sensation of hands and feet for the past 3 months. She has no history of diabetes. questions.text: A police officer has brought the following bullets to you for forensic examination as they were recovered while investigating a crime scene. What is the type of bullet shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The bullet shown in the given image possesses crossed grooves at its tips, which indicates that it is a dum-dum bullet.

Dum-dum bullets are not entirely covered by a jacket; an area near the nose is left uncovered to expose the core. These bullets are designed to expand upon hitting a target. This expansion increases the bullet's diameter, causing a larger wound channel.

Other options:

Option A: A souvenir bullet is one that has been lodged in the body for a long time, with no fresh bleeding around it, and is surrounded by a dense fibrous tissue capsule. 

Option B: Tracer bullets (shown in the image below) leave a visible trace while in flight, which allows the gunner to observe its trajectory. 

Option D: Tandem bullet phenomenon occurs when two bullets are expelled with a single shot; it is seen in the case of firearms that have remained unused or exposed to high temperature and humidity. 

Related Pearl: Types of bullets:

1. Ricochet bullet: Bullet first strikes an intermediate object and then after being reflected strikes the target. It produces a key hole entry wound .

2. Yawning bullet: Travels in an irregular fashion.

3. Tandem (Piggy Back) Bullet Effect: Two bullets are ejected one after the other; first bullet failed to leave the barrel and is ejected by subsequently fired bullet. This occurs due to defect in the weapon or due to faulty ammunition or with loaded firearms unused for several years. Tandem cartridge (also called duplex cartridge) is a single cartridge containing two bullets. 

 

4. Frangible bullet: Fragments on hitting the target.

5. Dum Dum bullet: Tip is chiseled out, fragments extensively on impact.

6. Tumbling bullet:  Rotates end on end during its motion. This produces an atypical entry wound .  

7. Souvenir bullet:  Bullet left in the body for a long time and covered with dense fibrous connective tissue.

8. Tracer bullet: This type of bullet leaves a visible mark or trace while in flight so that the gunner can observe the strike of shot. Rear portion of bullet is filled with mixture of barium nitrate, strontium nitrate and powdered magnesium which is ignited by the burning powder. Mixture burns and sheds red sparks which makes the projectile visible to naked eye which enables shooter to make aiming corrections.

9. Incendiary bullet: It is filled with white phosphorous and ignites the target.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of death in smothering?
questions.solution:
Slow asphyxia is the mechanism of death in smothering. 

Smothering is a type of asphyxia that is caused by closing the external respiratory openings (nose, mouth) either by the hand or by inserting a foreign substance (cloth, mud) into them. 

Smothering can be: 

  • Suicide - Commonly seen in psychiatric patients and prisoners. Self-smothering is not possible using the hand. Thus, suicide is attempted either by the burial of the face in a mattress or by tying a polythene bag over the head.
  • Homicidal - It is a simple and convenient method of homicide. It is a type of gentle homicide and is difficult to prove as it leaves no evidence. Usually, the things used to smother are - cloth, a pillow, or a hand
  • Accidental - Commonly seen in intoxicated, epileptics, and children. In intoxicated or epileptics, smothering may occur due to accidental burial of the face in the pillow. In children, smothering may occur due to accidental suffocation while playing with plastic bags

 The image below shows a picture showing smothering by a pillow and hand:

Other options:

Options A & D are mechanisms of death seen in hanging.

Option A: Death due to cerebral anemia can be seen in hanging. It occurs when the knot of the rope is placed at the nape of the neck which causes compression of the large vessels (both arteries and veins). This causes death within 10 to 15 seconds due to cerebral anemia and consequent coma.

Option D: Death due to venous congestion can be seen in hanging. It is particularly seen in cases where the knot is situated over the chin causing compression of the jugular veins. This in turn stops cerebral circulation leading to a rise in the venous pressure in the head and subsequent loss of consciousness. A tension of 2kgs is sufficient to occlude the jugular veins.

Option C: Death due to laryngeal spasm can be seen in drowning.

questions.text: A woman gave birth to twin babies of gestational ages differing by a few weeks. On detailed evaluation, it was noted that the disparity in gestational age of babies was due to fertilization of 2 different ova released in 2 different menstrual cycles. What is this phenomenon known as?
questions.solution:
The above phenomenon is known as superfetation. It occurs when there is fertilization of 2 different ova released in different menstrual cycles. The consequence is two children are born at the same time and one of them might be mature while another might be immature.

Ovulation usually stops with the onset of pregnancy, but in a few individuals, ovulation may be possible till the first trimester, after which the decidual cavity is obliterated. The fertilization of the newly released ovum in a woman who is already pregnant may take place following coitus. 

Other options:

Option A: Superfecundation is the fertilization of 2 different ova in the same menstrual cycle by separate acts of coitus. Heteropaternal superfecundation is used to refer to instances of two different males fathering fraternal twins. This leads to the possibility of twins also being half-siblings. This may raise doubts regarding adultery and infidelity. 

Option C: A supposititious child is also known as a fictitious child. In such cases, a woman pretends to be pregnant and substitutes a living child as her own, or may substitute a male child for her female child, or abortion. This is done to claim property. This can be identified by verifying the signs of pregnancy and delivery in the woman and by DNA fingerprinting.

Option D: Atavism is the reappearance of a characteristic in an individual after several generations of absence. For example, the child may not resemble his parents but resembles his grandparents. This is attributed to the recombination of genes.

questions.text:
A child is brought to the OPD with a history of repeated injuries that seem to be non-accidental. A diagnosis of battered baby syndrome is suspected. Which of the following clinical features are characteristic of the condition?
  1. Subdural hemorrhage
  2. Laceration over forehead
  3. "String of beads" appearance on chest x-ray
  4. Bucket-handle fracture
  5. Bruise over knee
questions.solution:
Statements 1, 3, and 4 are characteristic features of battered baby syndrome.

The battered baby syndrome refers to a constellation of clinical findings suggestive of repetitive physical abuse in a child via non-accidental violence by a parent or a guardian. Additionally, there may be associated deprivation of nutrition, care, and affection. It is usually seen in children less than 3 years of age with a history of emotional or financial problems in the family.

Clinical features:

  • Injuries of different ages and in different stages of healing
  • Bruises may be seen on either side of the chest, behind the axillae, and down the anterior chest wall indicative of the hand impressions of the perpetrator.
  • Violent shaking of a child leads to infantile whiplash syndrome. Repetitive and vigorous shaking of an infant gives rise to a triad of clinical findings—encephalopathy, retinal bleeds, and subdural hemorrhage. 
  • Multiple deformities of the long bones and ribs. Some characteristic fractures include the following:
    • Knob fractures are a result of callus formation in healing ribs that have been damaged due to squeezing. Chest x-ray shows a "string of beads" appearance in the paravertebral gutter.
    • Bucket-handle fractures are typical corner fractures near the metaphyseal regions of the long bones in the arms and legs.

Other statements:

Forehead lacerations, knee bruises, and injuries on bony prominences are non-specific features that may be due to age-appropriate falls. They are usually accidental and not characteristic of the condition.

questions.text: While dissecting the neck region during an autopsy, a Forensic Medicine resident observes the presence of Prinsloo-Gordon hemorrhages. Where are these hemorrhages located?

choices.text: On the lateral aspect of the larynx
Posterior longitudinal ligament of cervical vertebra
Beneath the ligature mark in hanging

questions.solution:
Prinsloo-Gordon hemorrhages are post-mortem artifacts seen over the posterior aspect of the esophagus and on the anterior longitudinal ligament of the cervical spine. 

Artefactual blood extravasation into the neck tissues can manifest as patches of bleeding during neck dissection. These were fully investigated by Prinsloo and Gordon and hence given the name. These artifacts mimic the bruises that result from manual strangulation and occasionally from spurious neck fractures.

In cases where neck trauma is suspected (like strangulation or hanging), it is advisable to remove the brain first or to open the chest and incise the great veins in the superior mediastinum, before dissecting the neck, to allow drainage of the engorged venous plexuses that give rise to the artifact. This phenomenon is most likely to be seen in cases where there is a delay in autopsy.

questions.text: You are conducting an autopsy of a person who died a few hours back. You notice that the entire body is rigid with significant flexion in the fingers and toes. This phenomenon is most pronounced when the ATP level is reduced to:
questions.solution:
The presence of rigidity and significant flexion in the extremities is suggestive of cadaveric rigidity/ rigor mortis. This phenomenon is most pronounced when the ATP level is reduced to 15% of the normal.

Cadaveric rigidity refers to the state of stiffening of muscles after death. Individual cell death occurs during this stage. It is also known as postmortem stiffening, rigor mortis, or cadaveric stiffening. It usually begins 1-2 hours after death and gets well established by 9-12 hours.

ATP is required for the separation of actin and myosin filaments as well as the energy required for contraction during life. After death, ATP is gradually and irreversibly destroyed, causing an increase in the accumulation of lactates and phosphates in the muscles.

When ATP is reduced to a critical level, overlapping myosin and actin filaments combine to form a viscous and inextensible actomyosin link, which causes rigidity of muscle. The phenomenon of rigor mortis starts when the ATP level is reduced to 85% of the normal value. When the ATP level is reduced to 15%-20% and the lactic acid level is 0.3%, muscle rigidity is at its peak.

The sequential order in which cadaveric rigidity appears is given by Nysten's rule. Muscles are affected in the given order:

  • Involuntary muscles - heart
  • Eyelids
  • Neck and lower jaw
  • Face
  • Chest
  • Upper extremities
  • Abdomen
  • Legs
  • Fingers and toes

Medicolegal importance of rigor mortis:

  • It is a sign of death
  • Its extent helps in the estimation of the time of death
  • It depicts the position of the body at the time of death

questions.text: A 24-year-old man is being evaluated for organ donation after being declared brain dead. Which of the following reflexes can be elicited even after brain death?
questions.solution:
Knee jerk reflex can be elicited even after brain death

Peripheral reflexes may be present in patients after brainstem death as these reflex arcs don't depend on input from the brainstem.

Apart from these, the following can be seen in brain death and should not be interpreted as evidence for the function of the brainstem:

  • spontaneous movements of limbs
  • respiration-like movements causing intercostal expansion
  • autonomic signs like sweating, flushing, tachycardia
  • normal or sudden increases in blood pressure
  • deep tendon reflexes; superficial abdominal reflexes
  • Babinski reflex

The cardinal features of brain death include:

  1. Unresponsiveness or coma
  2. Apnea- impaired brainstem activity indicates damage to the medullary cardio-respiratory centers. This manifests as a loss of centrally controlled breathing.
  3. Absence of brainstem reflexes -
    • Cranial nerve II, III (optic and oculomotor)- absent direct and consensual light reflex. This is associated with dilated pupils measuring about 9 mm. 
    • Cranial nerve VIII (vestibulocochlear)- absent oculocephalic (Doll's eye phenomenon) and oculovestibular (unresponsive to caloric testing) reflexes.
    • Cranial nerve V, VII (trigeminal and facial)- absent corneal and jaw reflexes.
    • Cranial nerve IX, X (glossopharyngeal and vagus)- absent cough and gag reflexes.

questions.text: Which of the following organs is tested in Breslau’s second life test?
questions.solution:
In Breslau’s second life test, also known as the stomach-bowel test, the stomach and duodenum are tested. The test is done to determine whether a baby was born alive or not.

It works on the principle that some air is swallowed during respiration in a live-born child. Detecting the presence of this air in these organs constitutes the basis for this test.

Procedure :

The stomach and duodenum are removed separately with ligatures and placed in water. If they float, make a small cut while underwater to see air bubbles coming up. A floating organ giving out air bubbles when opened underwater is a positive test.

Interpretation:

A positive test favors live birth even in the absence of a positive hydrostatic lung test. This may happen if there had been some obstruction in the respiratory tract.

questions.text: Identify the type of skull fracture in the given image.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a pond fracture of skull.

It appears as an indentation or a buckling-in of the skull, without actual fracture. It is more commonly seen in infants due to the elasticity of the bones. They are caused by an obstetric forceps blade or a blow from a blunt object. The dura mater is not torn and usually the brain is not damaged .

Related Pearl: Types of skull vault fracture

Diastatic fracture/ sutural fracture - It involves the separation of sutures due to blow with a blunt weapon or from cerebral edema.

Fissured fracture/ linear fracture:

  • They are breaks in the bone that traverse the full thickness of the skull from the outer to inner table.
  • They are usually fairly straight with no bone displacement.
  • The common cause of injury is blunt force trauma where the impact energy transferred over a wide area of the skull.

Pond fracture/ indented fracture - It occurs in children due to elasticity of bones. 

Depressed fracture/ signature fracture - It is caused by a heavy weapon with a small striking surface. Its shape indicates the type of weapon which is produced (signature fracture).

Comminuted fracture/ spider-web fracture - It has a stellate appearance where there is no displacement of the fracture.

Ring fracture - It is usually caused due to a fall from height landing on feet. These occur in the posterior fossa around the foramen magnum.

questions.text: Gettler’s test is positive in:
questions.solution:
Gettler test is done for drowning. It estimates the chloride content of blood from both sides of the heart.

Normally, chloride content is equal in the right and left chambers of the heart (approx. 600 mg/100 ml). In freshwater drowning, due to hemodilution, the chloride content is decreased on the left side of the heart by 50%. In saltwater drowning due to hemoconcentration, the chloride content is increased in the left side of the heart by 30-40%.

This test is said to be negative in post-mortem drowning. 

Limitations of the test:

No value in atypical drowning, or congenital cardiac defects, if the drowning medium contains the same amount of chloride. There is a progressive loss of chlorine from blood after death. Therefore, the test has to be made within a reasonably short time after death.

Drowning:

Drowning is the process of experiencing respiratory impairment from submersion/immersion in liquid. Accidental drowning is the most common form of drowning, seen among fishermen, bathers, dock workers, intoxicated, and epileptics.

Pathophysiology:

In cases of seawater drowning, hypernatremia and myocardial anoxia are seen. Seawater being hypertonic to plasma causes a shift of fluid from the blood to alveoli causing pulmonary edema. There is a net decrease in blood volume causing hemoconcentration and a fall in blood pressure.

This hemoconcentration in seawater drowning causes increased viscosity of blood and myocardial anoxia leading to heart failure. Hyperkalemia is not seen in seawater drowning because RBCs get shrunken in contrast to freshwater drowning.

Freshwater is hypotonic to plasma and is rapidly absorbed from the alveoli into the RBCs resulting in hemodilution and hyponatremia. The RBCs finally swell up and lyse resulting in the release of intracellular potassium causing hyperkalemia. Increased intravascular blood volume combined with hyperkalemia causes arrhythmia.

Autopsy findings in drowning:

  • Froth in the air passages - The most useful autopsy sign in drowning. It consists of a proteinaceous exudate and surfactant mixed with the water of the drowning medium.
  • Waterlogging of the lung - Frothy fluid will exude from the bronchi when the lung is squeezed or when sectioned with a knife. 
  • Emphysema aqueosum - Overinflation of the lungs.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy was brought to the OPD following a sting on his toe. On examination, he had tachycardia and hypertension and his pupils were dilated. Local examination of the wound showed mild erythema. The arachnid responsible for the sting is shown below. Which of the following drugs is used to counteract these effects?
questions.solution:
The clinical stem with the image showing a scorpion points to a scorpion bite, for which prazosin acts as a physiological antidote counteracting the symptoms of tachycardia, hypertension, and mydriasis. 

Most scorpion stings cause pain at the site of the bite. Systemic toxicity occurs in <10% of stings but is more commonly seen in infants and children. The venom is a clear, colorless toxalbumen and is generally classified as either hemolytic or neurotoxic. The venom is a potent autonomic stimulator resulting in the release of massive amounts of catecholamines from the adrenals. It also has a direct effect on the myocardium.

It can present as neurotoxicity with restlessness or seizure-like activity, abnormal oculomotor function, and loss of pharyngeal muscle control leading to respiratory compromise. Tongue fasciculations and hypersalivation are also common. Cardiovascular toxicity from systemic envenomation includes tachycardia, hypertension, pulmonary edema, and cardiogenic shock.

If the scorpion has hemolytic venom, the reaction is mainly local, with edema, pain, and reddening. This usually lasts for one to two hours. 

Treatment:

  • Pain- Paracetamol, NSAIDs, or opioids 
  • Sedation for agitation, oculomotor abnormalities, uncoordinated neuromuscular activity, muscle spasms- Benzodiazepines 
  • Hypertension and pulmonary edema- Prazosin counteracts the adrenergic surge that can lead to these effects
  • Cardiogenic shock- Antivenom, prazosin, nitroglycerin, dobutamine
  • Cholinergic effects- Atropine
  • Supportive care, wound care

questions.text: A young boy presents to the emergency department after being at a party. He says he tasted a small colorful graphic blotting paper while at the party. Within minutes, he had started to feel his heart race, had profuse sweating and tremors, and was rushed to the hospital. Later, he develops extreme paranoia and extreme panic and starts crying. Examination of the eyes shows mydriasis. Which of the following drugs did he most likely consume?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) abuse. The patient developed extreme panic and paranoia after tasting a small colorful blotting paper, which is suggestive of a bad trip. Other features that support this diagnosis are palpitation, profuse sweating, tremors, and pupillary dilation.

LSD is the most powerful hallucinogen known to man. Increased sympathetic activity like tachycardia, hypertension, pupillary dilation, tremor, and fever can be seen within minutes of oral intake. Apart from this, the users may have psychiatric symptoms like visual illusions, extreme changes in mood, paranoid delusions, etc. Patients may experience bad trips, where they have panic episodes. Prolonged experience without further exposure to drugs known as “flashbacks" can also result from LSD use. 

Stopping the drug abruptly after continued use does not produce withdrawal symptoms. Management of bad trips due to LSD abuse involves supportive treatment with anxiolytics.

Other named effects of drug use:

  • Amotivational syndrome - Chronic use of cannabis may lead to amotivational syndrome with lethargy and lack of interest in day-to-day activities.
  • Run amok - This is a psychic disturbance resulting from continued use or sudden consumption of Cannabis and is characterized by a peculiar homicidal mania.
  • Magnan syndrome - This is a type of tactile hallucination seen in chronic users of cocaine where they feel as if grains of sand are under the skin or insects are creeping on the skin (formication)

Other options:

Option A: Cannabis intoxication causes feelings of detachment, euphoria, relaxation, decreased concentration, and attention span. Images appear vivid. There is increased thirst and appetite.

Option B: Amphetamine intoxication also gives rise to similar clinical features like tachycardia, hypertension, sweating, tremors, dilated pupils, and paranoia. However, the ingestion of blotting paper, makes LSD more likely.

Option D: Cocaine intoxication may also have similar features, like tachycardia, hypertension, sweating, dilated pupils, and altered behavior. It also causes anesthesia in the area that has been in direct contact with the drug. Magnan syndrome may also be seen.

Joule burn is a specific and diagnostic of contact with electricity and is found at the point of entry of the current. It is seen in accidents with high-tension currents. questions.text: Osteomyelitis of the jaw is seen in:
questions.solution:
Osteomyelitis of the jaw is seen in phosphorous poisoning.

Phosphorus is a non-metallic, inorganic irritant poison that affects cellular oxidation. It exists in two forms: white phosphorus, which is highly toxic, and red phosphorus, which is non-toxic. Phosphorus is utilized in fertilizers, vermin-killers, rodenticides, fireworks, and gunpowder.

The initial stage of acute poisoning through ingestion involves severe abdominal discomfort, vomiting, and diarrhea. Excreta and breath have a garlicky odor. Luminescent feces and vomit are characteristically seen. Direct contact with the skin can result in second and third-degree burns. Shock, hematemesis due to liver failure, and renal insufficiency are potential causes of death. 

Regular inhalation of phosphorus fumes, leading to chronic phosphorus poisoning, results in necrosis of the lower jaw around a decayed tooth. This condition is known as phossy jaw and is associated with the discharge of foul-smelling pus from multiple sinuses. This is a type of osteomyelitis of the jaw where, bone formation under the epiphyseal cartilage, Haversian, and marrow canals increases. This impairs the blood circulation to the bone, resulting in bone necrosis and sequestration.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with suspected poisoning was brought to the casualty by his friends. On examination, the finding shown below is seen. Which of the following is the likely poisoning in this case?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a carpopedal spasm which is seen in hypocalcemia. Oxalic acid poisoning is associated with hypocalcemia.

In oxalic acid poisoning, those who survive for a few hours develop hypocalcemia, because oxalic acid readily combines with the calcium ion in the body tissues and forms calcium oxalate.

The features of oxalic acid poisoning include tenderness in the epigastrium, nausea, followed by coffee ground-colored vomitus, severe thirst, diarrhea, electrolyte imbalance, and death.

Acute features of oxalic acid poisoning are mainly due to hypocalcemia such as: 

  • Muscle irritability
  • Tenderness
  • Tetany
  • Convulsions
  • Tingling of extremities
  • Coma
  • Collapse and death

Delayed features of oxalic acid poisoning include uremia. Urine is scanty with traces of albumin, blood, and calcium oxalate crystals (seen microscopically as envelope-shaped crystals). Large doses of oxalic acid cause shock and lead to death. 

Antidotes: Lime water, calcium lactate, calcium gluconate, calcium chloride, and chalk suspension in water or milk may be given orally, and act as specific antidotes, which form insoluble calcium oxalate and are excreted easily.

Medicolegal importance: Oxalic acid is used to erase writing in attempts at forgery.

questions.text: A drunk father was playing with his baby and fell asleep as shown in the image, resulting in the death of the baby. What type of suffocation is seen here?
questions.solution:
The type of suffocation seen in this scenario is overlaying.

Overlaying is a type of suffocation resulting from compression of the nose, mouth, and chest, preventing breathing. It occurs in cases when a parent, under the influence of alcohol shares the bed with an infant. The guardian accidentally rolls over the child during sleep, leading to accidental occlusion of the air passages. There will be limited movements of the thoracic cavity, resulting in the reduction or absence of respiratory movements. 

Postmortem findings: The face, nose, and chest of the child appear compressed and pale. The nostrils may be filled with blood-stained froth. The usual findings of asphyxia like intrathoracic petechiae may be found. Death occurs as a result of neurogenic cardiac arrest.

Medicolegal importance: It can be purely accidental. It may also be a case of infanticide. 

Other options:

Option A: Traumatic asphyxia is a type of suffocation resulting from respiratory arrest due to mechanical fixation of the chest that prevents the normal movement of the chest.

Option B: Burking is a type of homicidal asphyxial death comprising of smothering and traumatic asphyxia. In burking, the assaulter kneels or sits on the chest of the victim, preventing chest movements, and then covers the nose and mouth of the victim with his hands.

2. Vertebral artery
3. External jugular vein
questions.solution:
The sequence of occlusion of vessels with increasing pressure on the neck is external jugular vein - carotid artery - vertebral artery. Hence, option C (3 - 1 - 2) is the correct sequence.

Increasing pressure leads to gradual compression of the vessels of the neck. The external jugular system is the most vulnerable to initial compression. This results in the classic signs of congestion, edema, and petechiae above the line of neck compression. 

With increasing pressure, the arteries of the neck are next to be compressed. Arteries have higher internal pressures and are situated more deep in comparison to the veins. The carotid arteries are the first to be compressed followed by the vertebral arteries. Occlusion of bilateral carotid arteries results in immediate unconsciousness. Occlusion for over 4 mins results in irreversible cerebral damage.

questions.text:
Which of the following BNS sections is not related to grievous hurt?

BNS - Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita
IPC - Indian Penal Code
questions.solution:
BNS 114 / IPC 319 defines hurt (not grievous hurt) as including bodily pain, infirmity, or disease caused to any individual.

Grievous hurt or injury is defined to include injuries such as emasculation, permanent damage to eyesight (either eye), permanent hearing damage (either ear), damage to any member or joint, destruction or permanent impairment of the power of any member or joint, permanent disfigurement of the head or face, fracture or dislocation of bone or tooth, and any hurt that endangers the victim's life or causes them severe bodily pain thereby impairing their ability to follow their daily routine for 15 days (revised in BNS - Previously it was 20 days under IPC). 

Other options:

Option D: BNS 116 / IPC 320 - defines grievous hurt.

Option A: BNS 117(2) / IPC 325 - deals with punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt - imprisonment for up to seven years and a fine.

Option B: BNS 118(2) / IPC 326 - deals with punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt by dangerous weapons or means - life imprisonment or imprisonment for ten years and a fine

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient who is suffering from poorly controlled schizophrenia gets agitated and causes hurt to a victim. Which of the following rules may exempt the patient from criminal responsibility?
questions.solution:
A patient suffering from poorly controlled schizophrenia may be exempt from criminal responsibility as a result of Durham's rule.

Durham's rule states that an accused person is not criminally responsible for a crime if the crime is a result of a mental disease or defect. The various rules with regard to the criminal responsibility of the insane are mentioned below:

  • Curren's rule - an accused person is not criminally responsible if, at the time of the crime, he lacked the capacity to regulate his conduct as a result of mental disease or defect
  • Irresistible impulse act (New Hampshire doctrine) - A person is not criminally responsible if he knows the nature of his act is wrong, but is incapable of restraining himself from committing it as his free will has been affected by a mental illness
  • American Law Institute test - A person is not responsible for his crime if, at the time of the crime, he lacked the capacity to appreciate the criminality of the act
  • McNaughten's rule (BNS 22 ) - This is explained in the pearl below

Other options:

Option A: Nysten's rule describes the sequential onset of rigor mortis in the various muscle groups. The basic sequence of the rigor mortis begins from the head down the body, in that order. It disappears in the same order of appearance.

Option C: Ashley's rule or the “149 rule”, is used to determine the gender using the length of the sternum in the European skeleton. Male sternum measures more than 149 mm and female sternum measures less than 149 mm.

Option D: Casper's rule or dictum states that a body decomposes in the air twice as fast as submerged in water, and eight times faster as buried in earth.

Related Pearl: BNS section 22, M'Naghten's rule

M'Naghten's rule, BNS 22 (Previously - Section 84 IPC):  Criminal responsibility of the insane.

Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who, at the time of doing it, by reason of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to law.

questions.text: A forensic investigator arrives at a crime scene in a forest area. While collecting evidence, he finds some hair near the victim's body. Which of the following characteristics will confirm that the hair is of human origin?

choices.text: Large cuticular scales with wavy projections

questions.solution:
A medullary index of 0.2 is a feature of human hair.

The study of hair is known as trichology. 

Trait Human hair Animal hair
Appearance Fine and thin Coarse and thick
Scales Short and thin cuticular scales which are irregularly annular Large cuticular scales with wavy projections
Pigmentation Evenly distributed Uneven distribution with concentration in the medulla
Medullary index Below 0.3 Above 0.5
Medulla Varies considerably but is usually narrow Thick and continuous medulla
Cortex Thick and well-striated Thin


The medullary index of hair is the ratio of the diameter of the medulla to the diameter of the whole hair shaft. In humans, it is less than 0.3.

questions.text: A patient is brought with a suspected case of poisoning to the emergency department. Hemodialysis is ineffective for treating which of the following types of poisoning?
questions.solution:
Hemodialysis is not effective for the management of digoxin poisoning.

The efficiency of hemodialysis in drug overdose or intoxication depends on molecular weight, water solubility, protein binding, and distribution of the drug in the body. A drug can be removed by hemodialysis if it has:

  • low molecular weight
  • low volume of distribution
  • high solubility in water
  • minimal protein binding

Digoxin has a high volume of distribution. It is widely distributed in tissues such as the heart, skeletal muscles, liver, and kidneys. Hence, hemodialysis is not effective for the management of overdose or poisoning. Rather, overdose and resultant arrhythmias are managed with anti-digoxin Fab fragments (Digibind or Digifab).

Salicylate (option A), ethylene glycol (option B), and chloral hydrate (option D) poisoning can all be managed by hemodialysis. 

Related Pearl: Dialyzable and non-dialyzable drugs

Common dialyzable drugs: 

  • Barbiturates
  • Lithium
  • Salicylates
  • Theophylline/Caffeine (both are methylxanthines)
  • Methanol
  • Ethylene glycol
  • Sodium valproate
  • Isoniazid
  • Carbamazepine

Common Non-Dialyzable Drugs (AVOID Dialysis):

  • A- Amphetamines
  • V- Verapamil
  • O- Opiates, Organophosphorous
  • I- Imipramine
  • D- Digoxin
  • Dialysis- Diazepam

questions.text: Under police request, a genital examination is being conducted on a male suspect accused of rape. The doctor decides to do a Lugol's iodine test. This test is used for detecting:

choices.text: Presence or absence of smegma on the corona
Bruising of the frenulum of the prepuce
Presence of dried blood stains on the shaft
Presence of vaginal cells on the glans

questions.solution:
The Lugol's iodine test is used for the detection of vaginal cells on the glans of the penis in a male suspect accused of rape.

The Lugol's iodine test is done after cleaning the glans with filter paper. The filter paper is then exposed to vapors of Lugol's iodine. The development of brown color indicated the presence of vaginal epithelial cells. This is because of the presence of glycogen in these cells. The test can be positive up to the 4th day after the act of rape.

The examination of the genitals of the accused can also give other clues concerning rape. The presence of scratches or bruising indicates a struggle by the victim to prevent intercourse. Forceful penetration against a virgin hymen can also cause tearing or bruising of the frenulum of the prepuce and abrasion of the glans penis. Patchy reddening of the rim of the glans is commonly observed. Dried blood stains can also be found on the shaft of the penis and the adjoining regions. 

The absence of smegma on the glans indicates intercourse may have been performed but the presence of smegma rules out complete penetration. Other tests include the detection of vaginal and cervical cells, and the detection of the victim's DNA from the swabs of the penis.
